title: I have read Frederick Douglass' book on his escape from slavery. Are there any other people around this time who wrote similar accounts? - Quora

response.answer_text: When I saw this question, I became curious, so I looked it up. What I learned was fascinating. Narratives by escaped slaves were an extremely popular genre in the 19th century United States. Katherine Bailey mentioned 12 Years A Slave, by Solomon Northrup. Here are two more famous accounts of men who escaped slavery, plus Booker T. Washington's landmark autobiography. Narrative of William Wells Brown, A Fugitive Slave, Written By Himself, 1847. Narrative of the Adventures and Escape of Moses Roper, From American Slavery, 1848. Up From Slavery: An Autobiography, by Booker T. Washington, 1901. William Wells Brown and Moses Roper were about the same age as Frederick Douglass. Booker T. Washington was 40 years younger. Brown was born in Missouri and escaped from slavery when he was 19. He became a lecturer and activist in the North. Roper was born in North Carolina. He was sold several times to owners in different states and attempted to escape from many, if not all of them. He was finally sold to a Florida plantation owner. From there, he made his successful escape in 1834. Roper boarded a schooner to England and became a speaker in the anti-slavery movement. England had abolished slavery the year before Roper arrived. Eventually he married an Englishwoman and moved to Canada to live the rest of his life as a farmer. Both books describe the brutality and torture they experienced as slaves. The authors wrote about their thoughts concerning slavery and society. Brown reflected on the contradictions he saw between the Christianity espoused by Southerners and their behavior as slaveholders. Booker T. Washington was born in Virginia. He became free after the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863. After describing his years as a child slave, his book focuses on his struggles to get an education at the Hampton Institute, and then on his work founding vocational schools, including the Tuskegee Institute. According to Wikipedia, Up From Slavery was the best-selling autobiography by an African-American until The Autobiography of Malcolm X was published in 1965. Slave Narratives: William Wells Brown's Narrative of a Fugitive Slave Narrative of My Escape from Slavery

Yes; there are several thousand first-person narratives going back to the early Atlantic slave trade, and over 200 published as books or pamphlets. Solomon Northup’s is the most famous, having been made twice into a feature film (mostly recently the award-winning 12 Years a Slave. And here’s a great resource for some of them: About this Collection - Born in Slavery: Slave Narratives from the Federal Writers' Project, 1936-1938 The dialect of many of the narratives seems stereotypical and offensive to us today, but there’s an interesting note on the language that explains why we should consider it in the context of the time. Other resources: American Slave Narratives Personal Accounts
